<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>Data</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 591, 120]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 135, 640, 152]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 166, 625, 183]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 197, 630, 214]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 229, 630, 246]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 260, 630, 277]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 291, 648, 308]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 322, 630, 339]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 353, 650, 370]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \text{ J K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 384, 688, 401]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^2 \text{ kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 415, 650, 432]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \text{ F m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 433, 650, 465]]<|/det|>
\[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 477, 635, 494]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 508, 688, 525]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{ W m}^{-2} \text{ K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 567, 168, 582]]<|/det|>
<form>Formulae</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 599, 583, 616]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 616, 581, 636]]<|/det|>
\[\nu^2 = u^2 + 2as\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 650, 556, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 681, 536, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F = \rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 714, 560, 744]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_0 = \frac{f_s V}{\nu \pm \nu_s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 761, 560, 777]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I = Anvq\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 792, 608, 809]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 823, 615, 852]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 284, 87]]<|/det|>
Define velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 131, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
In an experiment, two objects A and B are released from the side of a building, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 203, 787, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 501, 589, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 781, 551]]<|/det|>
Object A is released from rest at a height of \(10.0 \text{m}\) above horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 546, 918, 598]]<|/det|>
Object B is released with an initial upward velocity of \(3.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at a height \(h\) above the ground. Both objects take the same time to reach the ground and they do not collide with each other. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 610, 256, 628]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 763, 920, 782]]<|/det|>
<form>h = .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In a second experiment, object B is released from the same height as in **(b)** but with a speed of \(6.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the vertical, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 114, 640, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 294, 534, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 325, 180, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 325, 918, 359]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the time taken for object B to reach the ground is less than, the same as, or greater than the time taken in the first experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 428, 918, 447]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 464, 181, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 464, 918, 498]]<|/det|>
By considering energy, state and explain whether the speed at which object B reaches the ground is less than, the same as, or greater than in the first experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 602, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 603, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 141, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 71, 512, 89]]<|/det|>
Define the moment of a force about a pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 133, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
Three objects A, B and C are placed on a horizontal beam. The beam is in equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 207, 803, 381]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 399, 591, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 507, 450]]<|/det|>
The beam is uniform and has length \(9.0 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 470, 465]]<|/det|>
A pivot is at the midpoint of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 616, 479]]<|/det|>
Object A has mass \(90\mathrm{kg}\) and is at one end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 672, 495]]<|/det|>
Object B has mass \(m\) and is a distance of \(3.0 \text{m}\) from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 491, 672, 510]]<|/det|>
Object C has mass \(150\mathrm{kg}\) and is at the other end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 185, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 301, 542]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 724, 920, 743]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... $kg$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 724, 922, 743]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Object A is removed and replaced by a wire fixed to the end of the beam and to the ground, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 114, 868, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 269, 534, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 300, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
After the change, the beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium. The positions of B and C are unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 348, 772, 367]]<|/det|>
The wire has a diameter of \(1.8 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}\) and has a strain of \(1.2 \times 10^{- 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 361, 672, 381]]<|/det|>
The wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 393, 532, 412]]<|/det|>
Calculate the Young modulus of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
<form>Young modulus = .................................................... $Pa$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 612, 180, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
Object B is now moved to a new position closer to the pivot without passing it. The beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 658, 787, 677]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, that this has on the strain in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 782, 920, 800]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1500\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling along a straight horizontal road at constant velocity \(v\). The car is subject to a total resistive force \(F\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 114, 828, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 293, 534, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 324, 146, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 324, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
Show that the power \(P\) developed by the engine in overcoming the total resistive force is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 368, 534, 386]]<|/det|>
\[P = F\nu .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 542, 917, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 572, 148, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 571, 675, 590]]<|/det|>
The car now moves up a slope at a constant speed of \(30 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 732, 604]]<|/det|>
The slope is at an angle to the horizontal of \(6.0^{\circ}\), as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 616, 833, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 753, 534, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 785, 581, 803]]<|/det|>
The total resistive force acting on the car is \(1600 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Show that the increase in gravitational potential energy of the car in a time of 1.0 s is 46 000 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 257, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
Use the information in (b)(i) to determine the power developed by the engine to move the car up the slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 425, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<form>power = ............................................... W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 907, 477]]<|/det|>
The car picks up a passenger and then continues up the slope at the same speed as in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 667, 508]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, that the passenger has on:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 180, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 520, 482, 539]]<|/det|>
the air resistance acting on the car

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 613, 180, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 613, 490, 631]]<|/det|>
the power developed by the engine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 685, 920, 703]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 707, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 151, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 562, 89]]<|/det|>
State the principle of conservation of momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 196, 151, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 196, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
An object A of mass \(4.0\mathrm{kg}\) travels at a velocity of \(6.0\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) to the right on a horizontal frictionless surface. It moves towards a second object B of mass \(2.0\mathrm{kg}\) that is moving at a velocity of \(3.0\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) in the same direction as A, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 304, 273]]<|/det|>
object A, mass \(4.0\mathrm{kg}\)

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 255, 888, 368]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 384, 532, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 415, 890, 433]]<|/det|>
Object A collides with object B. The two objects join and move off together with velocity \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 447, 243, 464]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 180, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 277, 496]]<|/det|>
velocity \(v\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 585, 918, 603]]<|/det|>
<form>v = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 617, 180, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 616, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
the percentage of the total initial kinetic energy of the two objects that is transferred to other forms of energy during the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 787, 920, 805]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 817, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 817, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 532, 89]]<|/det|>
State why sound waves cannot be polarised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 133, 900, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 818, 183]]<|/det|>
A plane-polarised light wave is incident on a polarising filter as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 190, 821, 327]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 370, 566, 389]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the light incident on the filter is \(I_{\mathrm{0}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
The light is incident normally on the filter and the transmission axis of the filter is initially perpendicular to the plane of polarisation of the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 836, 465]]<|/det|>
The filter is now rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) about the direction of travel of the light wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 181, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 477, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.2, sketch the variation of the intensity \(I\) of the transmitted light with the angle of rotation \(\alpha\) as the filter is rotated through \(360^{\circ}\) from its initial position.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 521, 730, 698]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 718, 532, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 732, 920, 751]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 866, 91]]<|/det|>
The amplitude of the incident light wave is \(A_0\) when the intensity of the wave is \(I_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Use Malus's law to determine, in terms of \(A_0\), the amplitude of the transmitted wave when \(\alpha = 20^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 333, 920, 353]]<|/det|>
<form>amplitude = .................................................... $A_0$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 364, 920, 382]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 146, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 69, 437, 88]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by diffraction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 131, 918, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 148, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
Light of wavelength \(720 \text{nm}\) in a vacuum is incident normally on a diffraction grating as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[67, 205, 925, 562]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 571, 591, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 920, 637]]<|/det|>
A screen is parallel to the grating. An interference pattern is seen on the screen and the angle between the second-order maxima is \(52^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 185, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A nichrome resistance wire has length \(150 \text{cm}\), cross-sectional area \(2.45 \times 10^{- 7} \text{m}^2\) and resistivity \(1.12 \times 10^{- 6} \Omega \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 146, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 118, 680, 137]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<form>resistance = ............................................... \(\Omega\) [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
The nichrome wire forms part of a potentiometer circuit together with a cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(1.2 \text{V}\) and negligible internal resistance, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 345, 752, 575]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 591, 591, 610]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 622, 576, 640]]<|/det|>
The circuit is used to determine the e.m.f. of cell X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 653, 920, 687]]<|/det|>
The galvanometer is used in a null method to find the null point \(64 \text{cm}\) from the left-hand end of the nichrome wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 303, 920, 337]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|> An antiparticle equivalent of the neutron is called the antineutron. The quarks in the antineutron are the antiparticles of the quarks in a neutron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 390, 135]]<|/det|> The elementary charge is \(e\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|> In Table 8.1, state the flavour and charge of the three antiquarks that comprise the antineutron. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 182, 539, 199]]<|/det|> Table 8.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 211, 670, 332]]<|/det|>
flavourcharge/e
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 327, 920, 345]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 146, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 358, 544, 377]]<|/det|> In \(\beta^{-}\) decay, a neutron decays to form a proton. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 920, 422]]<|/det|> Theory predicts that an antineutron should decay to form an antiproton. A particle and an antiparticle should also be observed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 603, 454]]<|/det|> Suggest the names of the particle and the antiparticle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 920, 485]]<|/det|> particle: .................................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 920, 514]]<|/det|> antiparticle: ............................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 512, 920, 530]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 543, 920, 561]]<|/det|> [Total: 5]
